Have you ever been waiting in line
at the grocery store, innocently perusing the magazine rack,
when a song pops into your head? Not the whole song, but a fragment of it
that plays and replays until you find yourself unloading
the vegetables in time to the beat. You've been struck by an earworm,
and you're not alone. Over 90% of people are plagued
by earworms at least once a week, and about a quarter of people
experience them several times a day. They tend to burrow in during tasks
that don't require much attention, say, when waiting on water to boil or a traffic light to change. This phenomenon is one 
of the mind's great mysteries. Scientists don't know 
exactly why it's so easy for tunes to get stuck in our heads. From a psychological perspective, earworms are an example of mental imagery. This imagery can be visual, like when you close your eyes
and imagine a red wagon, or it can be auditory, like when you imagine
the sound of a baby screaming, or oil sizzling in a pan. Earworms are a special form 
of auditory imagery because they're involuntary. You don't plug your ears
and try to imagine "Who Let the Dogs Out," or, well, you probably don't. It just intrudes onto 
your mental soundscape and hangs around 
like an unwanted house guest. Earworms tend to be quite vivid and they're normally made up of a tune,
rather than, say, harmonies. A remarkable feature of earworms
is their tendency to get stuck in a loop, repeating again and again
for minutes or hours. Also remarkable is the role
of repetition in sparking earworms. Songs tend to get stuck when 
we listen to them recently and repeatedly. If repetition is such a trigger, then perhaps we can blame our earworms
on modern technology. The last hundred years have seen
an incredible proliferation of devices that help you listen 
to the same thing again and again. Records, cassettes, CDs, 
or streamed audio files. Have these technologies bread some
kind of unique, contemporary experience, and are earworms just a product
of the late 20th century? The answer comes from an unlikely source: Mark Twain. In 1876, just one year 
before the phonograph was invented, he wrote a short story
imagining a sinister takeover of an entire town by a rhyming jingle. This reference, and others, show us that earworms seem 
to be a basic psychological phenomenon, perhaps exacerbated 
by recording technology but not new to this century. So yes, every great historical figure,
from Shakespeare to Sacajawea, may well have wandered around
with a song stuck in their head. Besides music, it's hard to think
of another case of intrusive imagery that's so widespread. Why music? Why don't watercolors 
get stuck in our heads? Or the taste of cheesy taquitos? One theory has to do with the way music
is represented in memory. When we listen to a song we know, we're constantly hearing forward in time,
anticipating the next note. It's hard for us to think about one
particular musical moment in isolation. If we want to think about the pitch
of the word "you" in "Happy Birthday," we have to start back at "Happy," and sing through until we get to "you." In this way, a tune 
is sort of like a habit. Just like once you start tying your shoe, you're on automatic 
until you tighten the bow, once a tune is suggested because, for example, someone says,
"my umbrella," we have to play through until it
reaches a natural stopping point, "ella, ella, ella." But this is largely speculation. The basic fact remains we don't know
exactly why we're susceptible to earworms. But understanding them better 
could give us important clues to the workings of the human brain. Maybe the next time we're plagued by a Taylor Swift tune 
that just won't go away, we'll use it as the starting point
for a scientific odyssey that will unlock important mysteries
about basic cognition. And if not, well, 
we can just shake it off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Most earworms are composed of a:
Options: A. Timbre, B. String of harmonies, C. Tune, D. Texture
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: Who wrote a short story about a rhyming jingle taking over a town in 1876? Options: A. Charles Dickens, B. Mark Twain, C. Jane Austen, D. Edgar Allan Poe Correct Option: B
Question 3: What are earworms? Options: A. A type of hearing disorder, B. Fragments of songs that get stuck in people's heads, C. A form of mental illness, D. A type of musical instrument, A. A type of hearing disorder, B. A fragment of a song that gets stuck in one's head, C. A form of mental illness, D. A type of musical instrument Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the current scientific understanding of why earworms occur? Options: A. It is fully understood and attributed to a specific cause, B. It is partially understood, but more research is needed, C. It is not fully understood, D. It is not a topic of scientific study, A. The causes are fully understood, B. The causes are partially understood, but more research is needed, C. The causes are not yet fully understood, D. Earworms are not a topic of scientific study Correct Option: C
Question 5: What could understanding earworms provide insights into? Options: A. The workings of the human heart, B. The workings of the human brain and basic cognition, C. The workings of the human liver, D. The workings of the human lungs Correct Option: B
Question 6: How could recognizing the role of repetition in sparking earworms be useful? Options: A. It could help people avoid getting songs stuck in their heads, B. It could help people get songs stuck in their heads, C. It could help people understand the lyrics of songs, D. It could help people compose music, A. It could help people avoid getting songs stuck in their heads, B. It could help people get songs stuck in their heads, C. It could improve music composition, D. It could enhance music appreciation Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the relationship between earworms and modern technology? Options: A. Modern technology is the sole cause of earworms, B. Modern technology has no impact on earworms, C. The relationship is complex, and technology may exacerbate earworms, D. Modern technology can cure earworms Correct Option: C
Question 8: What aspect of music may make it more susceptible to getting stuck in people's heads? Options: A. The harmony, B. The melody, C. The rhythm, D. The tune, A. Harmony, B. Melody, C. Rhythm, D. Tune Correct Option: D
Question 9: What could combining the idea that earworms are a form of auditory imagery with the fact that they tend to occur during tasks that don't require much attention lead to? Options: A. A new understanding of how the brain processes music, B. A new understanding of how the brain processes visual information, C. A new understanding of how the brain processes tactile information, D. A new understanding of how the brain processes olfactory information, A. A better understanding of music processing in the brain, B. A better understanding of visual information processing in the brain, C. A better understanding of tactile information processing in the brain, D. A better understanding of olfactory information processing in the brain Correct Option: A
Question 10: What concept could be explored further to understand how the brain automates certain tasks? Options: A. Earworms as a form of mental illness, B. Earworms as a habit, similar to tying one's shoe, C. Earworms as a form of hearing disorder, D. Earworms as a type of musical instrument Correct Option: B
Question 11: What could be used to evaluate and critique the theory that earworms are caused by the way music is represented in memory? Options: A. Its ability to explain the phenomenon, B. Its inability to explain the phenomenon, C. Its relevance to modern technology, D. Its relevance to music composition, A. By its ability to explain the phenomenon of earworms, B. By its inability to explain the phenomenon of earworms, C. By its relevance to modern technology, D. By its relevance to music composition Correct Option: A
Question 12: What could be evaluated and compared to other potential causes of earworms? Options: A. The idea that earworms are a form of mental illness, B. The idea that modern technology is responsible for the prevalence of earworms, C. The idea that earworms are a type of musical instrument, D. The idea that earworms are a form of hearing disorder, A. Earworms as a form of mental illness, B. The impact of modern technology on earworms, C. Earworms as a type of musical instrument, D. Earworms as a form of hearing disorder Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been waiting in line
at the grocery store, innocently perusing the magazine rack,
when a song pops into your head? Not the whole song, but a fragment of it
that plays and replays until you find yourself unloading
the vegetables in time to the beat. You've been struck by an earworm,
and you're not alone. Over 90% of people are plagued
by earworms at least once a week, and about a quarter of people
experience them several times a day. They tend to burrow in during tasks
that don't require much attention, say, when waiting on water to boil or a traffic light to change. This phenomenon is one 
of the mind's great mysteries. Scientists don't know 
exactly why it's so easy for tunes to get stuck in our heads. From a psychological perspective, earworms are an example of mental imagery. This imagery can be visual, like when you close your eyes
and imagine a red wagon, or it can be auditory, like when you imagine
the sound of a baby screaming, or oil sizzling in a pan. Earworms are a special form 
of auditory imagery because they're involuntary. You don't plug your ears
and try to imagine "Who Let the Dogs Out," or, well, you probably don't. It just intrudes onto 
your mental soundscape and hangs around 
like an unwanted house guest. Earworms tend to be quite vivid and they're normally made up of a tune,
rather than, say, harmonies. A remarkable feature of earworms
is their tendency to get stuck in a loop, repeating again and again
for minutes or hours. Also remarkable is the role
of repetition in sparking earworms. Songs tend to get stuck when 
we listen to them recently and repeatedly. If repetition is such a trigger, then perhaps we can blame our earworms
on modern technology. The last hundred years have seen
an incredible proliferation of devices that help you listen 
to the same thing again and again. Records, cassettes, CDs, 
or streamed audio files. Have these technologies bread some
kind of unique, contemporary experience, and are earworms just a product
of the late 20th century? The answer comes from an unlikely source: Mark Twain. In 1876, just one year 
before the phonograph was invented, he wrote a short story
imagining a sinister takeover of an entire town by a rhyming jingle. This reference, and others, show us that earworms seem 
to be a basic psychological phenomenon, perhaps exacerbated 
by recording technology but not new to this century. So yes, every great historical figure,
from Shakespeare to Sacajawea, may well have wandered around
with a song stuck in their head. Besides music, it's hard to think
of another case of intrusive imagery that's so widespread. Why music? Why don't watercolors 
get stuck in our heads? Or the taste of cheesy taquitos? One theory has to do with the way music
is represented in memory. When we listen to a song we know, we're constantly hearing forward in time,
anticipating the next note. It's hard for us to think about one
particular musical moment in isolation. If we want to think about the pitch
of the word "you" in "Happy Birthday," we have to start back at "Happy," and sing through until we get to "you." In this way, a tune 
is sort of like a habit. Just like once you start tying your shoe, you're on automatic 
until you tighten the bow, once a tune is suggested because, for example, someone says,
"my umbrella," we have to play through until it
reaches a natural stopping point, "ella, ella, ella." But this is largely speculation. The basic fact remains we don't know
exactly why we're susceptible to earworms. But understanding them better 
could give us important clues to the workings of the human brain. Maybe the next time we're plagued by a Taylor Swift tune 
that just won't go away, we'll use it as the starting point
for a scientific odyssey that will unlock important mysteries
about basic cognition. And if not, well, 
we can just shake it off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A story by Mark Twain is one piece of evidence that:
Options: A. Only people in certain cultures are susceptible to earworms, B. Earworms existed before the advent of modern recording technology, C. Earworms are not important, D. Earworms can be cured
Correct Option: B

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Have you ever been waiting in line
at the grocery store, innocently perusing the magazine rack,
when a song pops into your head? Not the whole song, but a fragment of it
that plays and replays until you find yourself unloading
the vegetables in time to the beat. You've been struck by an earworm,
and you're not alone. Over 90% of people are plagued
by earworms at least once a week, and about a quarter of people
experience them several times a day. They tend to burrow in during tasks
that don't require much attention, say, when waiting on water to boil or a traffic light to change. This phenomenon is one 
of the mind's great mysteries. Scientists don't know 
exactly why it's so easy for tunes to get stuck in our heads. From a psychological perspective, earworms are an example of mental imagery. This imagery can be visual, like when you close your eyes
and imagine a red wagon, or it can be auditory, like when you imagine
the sound of a baby screaming, or oil sizzling in a pan. Earworms are a special form 
of auditory imagery because they're involuntary. You don't plug your ears
and try to imagine "Who Let the Dogs Out," or, well, you probably don't. It just intrudes onto 
your mental soundscape and hangs around 
like an unwanted house guest. Earworms tend to be quite vivid and they're normally made up of a tune,
rather than, say, harmonies. A remarkable feature of earworms
is their tendency to get stuck in a loop, repeating again and again
for minutes or hours. Also remarkable is the role
of repetition in sparking earworms. Songs tend to get stuck when 
we listen to them recently and repeatedly. If repetition is such a trigger, then perhaps we can blame our earworms
on modern technology. The last hundred years have seen
an incredible proliferation of devices that help you listen 
to the same thing again and again. Records, cassettes, CDs, 
or streamed audio files. Have these technologies bread some
kind of unique, contemporary experience, and are earworms just a product
of the late 20th century? The answer comes from an unlikely source: Mark Twain. In 1876, just one year 
before the phonograph was invented, he wrote a short story
imagining a sinister takeover of an entire town by a rhyming jingle. This reference, and others, show us that earworms seem 
to be a basic psychological phenomenon, perhaps exacerbated 
by recording technology but not new to this century. So yes, every great historical figure,
from Shakespeare to Sacajawea, may well have wandered around
with a song stuck in their head. Besides music, it's hard to think
of another case of intrusive imagery that's so widespread. Why music? Why don't watercolors 
get stuck in our heads? Or the taste of cheesy taquitos? One theory has to do with the way music
is represented in memory. When we listen to a song we know, we're constantly hearing forward in time,
anticipating the next note. It's hard for us to think about one
particular musical moment in isolation. If we want to think about the pitch
of the word "you" in "Happy Birthday," we have to start back at "Happy," and sing through until we get to "you." In this way, a tune 
is sort of like a habit. Just like once you start tying your shoe, you're on automatic 
until you tighten the bow, once a tune is suggested because, for example, someone says,
"my umbrella," we have to play through until it
reaches a natural stopping point, "ella, ella, ella." But this is largely speculation. The basic fact remains we don't know
exactly why we're susceptible to earworms. But understanding them better 
could give us important clues to the workings of the human brain. Maybe the next time we're plagued by a Taylor Swift tune 
that just won't go away, we'll use it as the starting point
for a scientific odyssey that will unlock important mysteries
about basic cognition. And if not, well, 
we can just shake it off.

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been waiting in line
at the grocery store, innocently perusing the magazine rack,
when a song pops into your head? Not the whole song, but a fragment of it
that plays and replays until you find yourself unloading
the vegetables in time to the beat. You've been struck by an earworm,
and you're not alone. Over 90% of people are plagued
by earworms at least once a week, and about a quarter of people
experience them several times a day. They tend to burrow in during tasks
that don't require much attention, say, when waiting on water to boil or a traffic light to change. This phenomenon is one

and imagine a red wagon, or it can be auditory, like when you imagine

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Music is especially susceptible to getting stuck in our heads because:
Options: A. Most people like music, B. It isn't; other things are equally likely to get stuck in our heads, C. Music is similar to language, D. We don't know exactly why
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the fall of 1845, the bright green
leaves of potato plants dotted the Irish countryside. For over 200 years, 
the South American vegetable had thrived in Ireland’s rough terrain
and unpredictable weather. Packed with carbohydrates,
vitamins, and minerals, the potato was a remarkably
nutrient-rich crop that made it easy for less wealthy
families to maintain a balanced diet. By the mid-19th century, potatoes had
supplanted other staple foods. And since British mandates ensured
Ireland’s more valuable agricultural products were exported, roughly half the country’s
8.5 million residents lived almost entirely on potatoes. But when harvesting began in 1845, farmers found their potatoes
blackened and shriveled. Those who ate them suffered severe
stomach cramps and even death. Today, we know the culprit was
Phytophthora infestans— a fungus that flourished in the season’s
unusually damp weather. But at the time it was simply
called “the blight.” The fungus likely originated
in the Americas, traveling across the Atlantic on ships. And while it destroyed potato harvests
across Europe, wealthier countries— then as today—
generally fared better, as they had more resources to draw on. Meanwhile, the southern and western
regions of Ireland were already impoverished
and entirely dependent on the single crop, making them disproportionately vulnerable. The impacts of food insecurity are often
most severe at the poverty line. But while the failed harvest
created a class crisis, the government's response turned
it into a national catastrophe. For centuries, Ireland had been
under varying degrees of English control, and by 1845,
it was part of the United Kingdom with its government based in London. During the famine’s first year, this distant ruling body imported corn
from North America and offered the Irish employment
on public works projects. But this relief only caused more problems. Imported food was poorly distributed
and offered insufficient nutrition, making the previously healthy population
more vulnerable to disease, and increasing maternal
and child mortality. Worse still, the British continued
to export Ireland’s grain and livestock. Meanwhile, the public works projects
required lengthy shifts of grueling manual labour and
were far from where most workers lived. For example, just one of countless tragic
incidences is the story of Thomas Malone, who walked 18 kilometers roundtrip
to work every day. One night, exhausted and starving, he collapsed and died
just before reaching home, leaving behind his wife and six children. Despite the year’s countless tragedies,
many families managed to scrape by. But in 1846, the damp weather returned
and the blight worsened, impacting 75% of Ireland's potato yield. British relief efforts diminished
substantially in the famine’s second year. And while international aid
helped save lives, the overall need was enormous. As the crisis wore on, the government
limited who was eligible for relief and tasked Ireland with funding the relief
efforts themselves by increasing local taxes. Most modern historians view these
disastrous policies as stemming from a mix
of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies,
and political infighting. British news sources callously
depicted the Irish as lazy, simple-minded alcoholics, and some London decision-makers believed
the famine was God’s punishment for these sinful behaviors. Other government officials purposefully
blocked efforts to provide meaningful relief
due to internal political rivalries. As with famines and food insecurity today, it wasn't a lack of resources preventing
the British from aiding Ireland, but rather a lack of political will. Seven years after the blight began, Ireland’s weather patterns
returned to normal and the potato crop finally stabilised. But over 1 million people had perished
from starvation, malnutrition, and disease. Between 1 and 2 million more
fled the country, beginning a trend that dropped Ireland’s
population to half its pre-famine levels by the 1920s. Today, climate change is making
extreme weather more common and sustained, leading countless agricultural communities
to face similar struggles. Just as in Ireland,
farmers living on the margins are increasingly facing starvation,
malnutrition, and disease due to global weather patterns
for which they bear little responsibility. But history doesn’t have to repeat itself
if governments and institutions can provide the kind of aid
these regions need: relief efforts that are coordinated
and ongoing, provide sufficient nutrition
to prevent disease, and are offered with compassion
rather than judgment.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the approximate population of Ireland before the famine?
Options: A. 2.5 million, B. 5.5 million, C. 6.5 million, D. 8.5 million
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what season did the Irish potato blight first appear in 1845? Options: A. Spring, B. Summer, C. Fall, D. Winter Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the primary cause of the potato blight that led to the Irish famine? Options: A. A virus, B. A fungus (Phytophthora infestans), C. A bacterial infection, D. A pest infestation Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the significance of the potato crop in Ireland's economy and diet in the mid-19th century? Options: A. It was a luxury item for the wealthy, B. It was a staple crop for a small portion of the population, C. It was a minor crop used for animal feed, D. It was the primary food source for the majority of the population Correct Option: D
Question 4: What was the impact of the blight on Ireland's food security and population? Options: A. It had a minimal effect on the population, B. It led to a significant increase in food production, C. It resulted in widespread food insecurity and a significant decline in population, D. It had no impact on the country's economy Correct Option: C
Question 5: What can be learned from the Irish potato famine about the impact of climate change on agricultural communities? Options: A. Climate change has no impact on agricultural communities, B. Climate change can lead to increased crop yields, C. Climate change can lead to increased food insecurity and vulnerability in agricultural communities, D. Climate change is not a significant factor in food security Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why are coordinated and ongoing relief efforts crucial in preventing and alleviating food insecurity and related crises? Options: A. They are not necessary and can be counterproductive, B. They are only necessary in extreme cases, C. They provide sufficient nutrition, prevent disease, and address the root causes of food insecurity, D. They are only the responsibility of the affected community Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did poverty and lack of resources exacerbate the severity of the famine in Ireland? Options: A. Poverty and lack of resources had no impact on the severity of the famine, B. Poverty and lack of resources alleviated the severity of the famine, C. Poverty and lack of resources made it difficult for people to access alternative food sources and increased their vulnerability to disease, D. Poverty and lack of resources were the sole causes of the famine Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the primary criticism of the British government's response to the famine? Options: A. It was adequate and met the needs of the Irish population, B. It was inadequate but well-intentioned, C. It was inadequate and reflected a flawed ideology that prioritized economic interests over human lives, D. It was not relevant to the famine Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do climate change, poverty, and food insecurity intersect to create vulnerable populations? Options: A. Climate change, poverty, and food insecurity are unrelated factors, B. Climate change and poverty are the primary causes of food insecurity, C. Climate change, poverty, and food insecurity intersect to create vulnerable populations, particularly in agricultural communities, D. Food insecurity is the sole cause of vulnerability in populations Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is it essential to consider historical context and power dynamics when understanding the impact of policies on marginalized communities? Options: A. Historical context and power dynamics are irrelevant in understanding policy impact, B. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in extreme cases, C. Historical context and power dynamics help to identify the root causes of inequality and inform more effective policy responses, D. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in understanding economic policies Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the role of ideology in shaping the British government's response to the famine? Options: A. The British government's response was based on a neutral, evidence-based assessment of the situation, B. The British government's response was influenced by a mix of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies, and political infighting, C. The British government's response was driven solely by economic interests, D. The British government's response was not influenced by ideology Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the justification for the need for coordinated and ongoing relief efforts in preventing similar crises? Options: A. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are not necessary and can be counterproductive, B. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are only necessary in extreme cases, C. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts can help to address the root causes of food insecurity, prevent disease, and reduce mortality, D. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are only the responsibility of the affected community Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

rather than judgment.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the fall of 1845, the bright green
leaves of potato plants dotted the Irish countryside. For over 200 years, 
the South American vegetable had thrived in Ireland’s rough terrain
and unpredictable weather. Packed with carbohydrates,
vitamins, and minerals, the potato was a remarkably
nutrient-rich crop that made it easy for less wealthy
families to maintain a balanced diet. By the mid-19th century, potatoes had
supplanted other staple foods. And since British mandates ensured
Ireland’s more valuable agricultural products were exported, roughly half the country’s
8.5 million residents lived almost entirely on potatoes. But when harvesting began in 1845, farmers found their potatoes
blackened and shriveled. Those who ate them suffered severe
stomach cramps and even death. Today, we know the culprit was
Phytophthora infestans— a fungus that flourished in the season’s
unusually damp weather. But at the time it was simply
called “the blight.” The fungus likely originated
in the Americas, traveling across the Atlantic on ships. And while it destroyed potato harvests
across Europe, wealthier countries— then as today—
generally fared better, as they had more resources to draw on. Meanwhile, the southern and western
regions of Ireland were already impoverished
and entirely dependent on the single crop, making them disproportionately vulnerable. The impacts of food insecurity are often
most severe at the poverty line. But while the failed harvest
created a class crisis, the government's response turned
it into a national catastrophe. For centuries, Ireland had been
under varying degrees of English control, and by 1845,
it was part of the United Kingdom with its government based in London. During the famine’s first year, this distant ruling body imported corn
from North America and offered the Irish employment
on public works projects. But this relief only caused more problems. Imported food was poorly distributed
and offered insufficient nutrition, making the previously healthy population
more vulnerable to disease, and increasing maternal
and child mortality. Worse still, the British continued
to export Ireland’s grain and livestock. Meanwhile, the public works projects
required lengthy shifts of grueling manual labour and
were far from where most workers lived. For example, just one of countless tragic
incidences is the story of Thomas Malone, who walked 18 kilometers roundtrip
to work every day. One night, exhausted and starving, he collapsed and died
just before reaching home, leaving behind his wife and six children. Despite the year’s countless tragedies,
many families managed to scrape by. But in 1846, the damp weather returned
and the blight worsened, impacting 75% of Ireland's potato yield. British relief efforts diminished
substantially in the famine’s second year. And while international aid
helped save lives, the overall need was enormous. As the crisis wore on, the government
limited who was eligible for relief and tasked Ireland with funding the relief
efforts themselves by increasing local taxes. Most modern historians view these
disastrous policies as stemming from a mix
of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies,
and political infighting. British news sources callously
depicted the Irish as lazy, simple-minded alcoholics, and some London decision-makers believed
the famine was God’s punishment for these sinful behaviors. Other government officials purposefully
blocked efforts to provide meaningful relief
due to internal political rivalries. As with famines and food insecurity today, it wasn't a lack of resources preventing
the British from aiding Ireland, but rather a lack of political will. Seven years after the blight began, Ireland’s weather patterns
returned to normal and the potato crop finally stabilised. But over 1 million people had perished
from starvation, malnutrition, and disease. Between 1 and 2 million more
fled the country, beginning a trend that dropped Ireland’s
population to half its pre-famine levels by the 1920s. Today, climate change is making
extreme weather more common and sustained, leading countless agricultural communities
to face similar struggles. Just as in Ireland,
farmers living on the margins are increasingly facing starvation,
malnutrition, and disease due to global weather patterns
for which they bear little responsibility. But history doesn’t have to repeat itself
if governments and institutions can provide the kind of aid
these regions need: relief efforts that are coordinated
and ongoing, provide sufficient nutrition
to prevent disease, and are offered with compassion
rather than judgment.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Correct Option: B

Question 10: Why is it essential to consider historical context and power dynamics when understanding the impact of policies on marginalized communities? Options: A. Historical context and power dynamics are irrelevant in understanding policy impact, B. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in extreme cases, C. Historical context and power dynamics help to identify the root causes of inequality and inform more effective policy responses, D. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in understanding economic policies Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the role of ideology in shaping the British government's response to the famine? Options: A. The British government's response was based on a neutral, evidence-based assessment of the situation, B. The British government's response was influenced by a mix of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies, and political infighting, C. The British government's response was driven solely by economic interests, D. The British government's response was not influenced by ideology Correct Option: B

Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts can help to address the root causes of food insecurity, prevent disease, and reduce mortality, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the fall of 1845, the bright green
leaves of potato plants dotted the Irish countryside. For over 200 years, 
the South American vegetable had thrived in Ireland’s rough terrain
and unpredictable weather. Packed with carbohydrates,
vitamins, and minerals, the potato was a remarkably
nutrient-rich crop that made it easy for less wealthy
families to maintain a balanced diet. By the mid-19th century, potatoes had
supplanted other staple foods. And since British mandates ensured
Ireland’s more valuable agricultural products were exported, roughly half the country’s
8.5 million residents lived almost entirely on potatoes. But when harvesting began in 1845, farmers found their potatoes
blackened and shriveled. Those who ate them suffered severe
stomach cramps and even death. Today, we know the culprit was
Phytophthora infestans— a fungus that flourished in the season’s
unusually damp weather. But at the time it was simply
called “the blight.” The fungus likely originated
in the Americas, traveling across the Atlantic on ships. And while it destroyed potato harvests
across Europe, wealthier countries— then as today—
generally fared better, as they had more resources to draw on. Meanwhile, the southern and western
regions of Ireland were already impoverished
and entirely dependent on the single crop, making them disproportionately vulnerable. The impacts of food insecurity are often
most severe at the poverty line. But while the failed harvest
created a class crisis, the government's response turned
it into a national catastrophe. For centuries, Ireland had been
under varying degrees of English control, and by 1845,
it was part of the United Kingdom with its government based in London. During the famine’s first year, this distant ruling body imported corn
from North America and offered the Irish employment
on public works projects. But this relief only caused more problems. Imported food was poorly distributed
and offered insufficient nutrition, making the previously healthy population
more vulnerable to disease, and increasing maternal
and child mortality. Worse still, the British continued
to export Ireland’s grain and livestock. Meanwhile, the public works projects
required lengthy shifts of grueling manual labour and
were far from where most workers lived. For example, just one of countless tragic
incidences is the story of Thomas Malone, who walked 18 kilometers roundtrip
to work every day. One night, exhausted and starving, he collapsed and died
just before reaching home, leaving behind his wife and six children. Despite the year’s countless tragedies,
many families managed to scrape by. But in 1846, the damp weather returned
and the blight worsened, impacting 75% of Ireland's potato yield. British relief efforts diminished
substantially in the famine’s second year. And while international aid
helped save lives, the overall need was enormous. As the crisis wore on, the government
limited who was eligible for relief and tasked Ireland with funding the relief
efforts themselves by increasing local taxes. Most modern historians view these
disastrous policies as stemming from a mix
of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies,
and political infighting. British news sources callously
depicted the Irish as lazy, simple-minded alcoholics, and some London decision-makers believed
the famine was God’s punishment for these sinful behaviors. Other government officials purposefully
blocked efforts to provide meaningful relief
due to internal political rivalries. As with famines and food insecurity today, it wasn't a lack of resources preventing
the British from aiding Ireland, but rather a lack of political will. Seven years after the blight began, Ireland’s weather patterns
returned to normal and the potato crop finally stabilised. But over 1 million people had perished
from starvation, malnutrition, and disease. Between 1 and 2 million more
fled the country, beginning a trend that dropped Ireland’s
population to half its pre-famine levels by the 1920s. Today, climate change is making
extreme weather more common and sustained, leading countless agricultural communities
to face similar struggles. Just as in Ireland,
farmers living on the margins are increasingly facing starvation,
malnutrition, and disease due to global weather patterns
for which they bear little responsibility. But history doesn’t have to repeat itself
if governments and institutions can provide the kind of aid
these regions need: relief efforts that are coordinated
and ongoing, provide sufficient nutrition
to prevent disease, and are offered with compassion
rather than judgment.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following do historians believe contributed to the government’s failure to offer adequate assistance to the Irish?
Options: A. Toxic religious ideology, B. Laissez-faire economic policies, C. Political infighting, D. All the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what season did the Irish potato blight first appear in 1845? Options: A. Spring, B. Summer, C. Fall, D. Winter Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the primary cause of the potato blight that led to the Irish famine? Options: A. A virus, B. A fungus (Phytophthora infestans), C. A bacterial infection, D. A pest infestation Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the significance of the potato crop in Ireland's economy and diet in the mid-19th century? Options: A. It was a luxury item for the wealthy, B. It was a staple crop for a small portion of the population, C. It was a minor crop used for animal feed, D. It was the primary food source for the majority of the population Correct Option: D
Question 4: What was the impact of the blight on Ireland's food security and population? Options: A. It had a minimal effect on the population, B. It led to a significant increase in food production, C. It resulted in widespread food insecurity and a significant decline in population, D. It had no impact on the country's economy Correct Option: C
Question 5: What can be learned from the Irish potato famine about the impact of climate change on agricultural communities? Options: A. Climate change has no impact on agricultural communities, B. Climate change can lead to increased crop yields, C. Climate change can lead to increased food insecurity and vulnerability in agricultural communities, D. Climate change is not a significant factor in food security Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why are coordinated and ongoing relief efforts crucial in preventing and alleviating food insecurity and related crises? Options: A. They are not necessary and can be counterproductive, B. They are only necessary in extreme cases, C. They provide sufficient nutrition, prevent disease, and address the root causes of food insecurity, D. They are only the responsibility of the affected community Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did poverty and lack of resources exacerbate the severity of the famine in Ireland? Options: A. Poverty and lack of resources had no impact on the severity of the famine, B. Poverty and lack of resources alleviated the severity of the famine, C. Poverty and lack of resources made it difficult for people to access alternative food sources and increased their vulnerability to disease, D. Poverty and lack of resources were the sole causes of the famine Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the primary criticism of the British government's response to the famine? Options: A. It was adequate and met the needs of the Irish population, B. It was inadequate but well-intentioned, C. It was inadequate and reflected a flawed ideology that prioritized economic interests over human lives, D. It was not relevant to the famine Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do climate change, poverty, and food insecurity intersect to create vulnerable populations? Options: A. Climate change, poverty, and food insecurity are unrelated factors, B. Climate change and poverty are the primary causes of food insecurity, C. Climate change, poverty, and food insecurity intersect to create vulnerable populations, particularly in agricultural communities, D. Food insecurity is the sole cause of vulnerability in populations Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is it essential to consider historical context and power dynamics when understanding the impact of policies on marginalized communities? Options: A. Historical context and power dynamics are irrelevant in understanding policy impact, B. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in extreme cases, C. Historical context and power dynamics help to identify the root causes of inequality and inform more effective policy responses, D. Historical context and power dynamics are only relevant in understanding economic policies Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the role of ideology in shaping the British government's response to the famine? Options: A. The British government's response was based on a neutral, evidence-based assessment of the situation, B. The British government's response was influenced by a mix of toxic religious ideology, laissez-faire economic policies, and political infighting, C. The British government's response was driven solely by economic interests, D. The British government's response was not influenced by ideology Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the justification for the need for coordinated and ongoing relief efforts in preventing similar crises? Options: A. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are not necessary and can be counterproductive, B. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are only necessary in extreme cases, C. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts can help to address the root causes of food insecurity, prevent disease, and reduce mortality, D. Coordinated and ongoing relief efforts are only the responsibility of the affected community Correct Option: C

across Europe, wealthier countries— then as today—

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: By the 1920’s, Ireland’s population had dropped to about _____ of its pre-famine levels.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast, white ice surface of Antarctica stretches for over 3 million
square kilometers: empty, desolate,
and almost completely silent. But appearances can be deceiving. On the coast of this expanse, just a few meters beneath the ice
lies a multicolored constellation of life. This remarkably diverse realm is home
to over 8,000 species of sea denizens who rely on an arsenal
of otherworldly traits to survive. So how do these species not only live,
but thrive, in conditions most animals
would be unable to bear? Antarctic waters are some of the most
consistently frigid in the world, hovering below 0 degrees Celsius
for a large portion of the year. This means burning energy
too quickly can be deadly, so survival in this ecosystem
looks slow and steady. Freezing temperatures persist
even in the summer, but this season brings
a rare gift: sunlight. For a brief period, it’s abundant, shining through the ice
for 24 hours a day. This infusion of energy drives intense
coastal phytoplankton blooms, transforming the waters
into a thick green soup. Marine life both large and small
takes advantage of this bounty, including the giant Antarctic isopod. Cousins of the humble pill bug, these crustaceans can reach
up to 11 centimeters long, and they never miss the opportunity
for a meal. The scavengers eat a wide variety of prey,
including other giant isopods. And by slowing their metabolisms,
they can make this food last, with one study showing specimens surviving
for 50 days without eating. Since this adaptation involves careful
conservation of energy, giant isopods spend most of their time
stationary or inching across the seafloor. Meanwhile, their tiny amphipod relatives
celebrate the summer by releasing offspring
alongside the algal explosion, ensuring their young have
an abundance of food. And sea cucumbers carpeting the seafloor
hoover up the dense plankton with outstretched
tentacles, producing nutrient-rich feces
that nourish nearby life. But this big summer blowout
doesn’t last long. The first signs of autumn arrive
in fine needles of frazil ice. These slowly coagulating crystals
form a skin across the surface, then mix with falling snow
before freezing into a thin crust of ice. The waters get darker and colder. And in this swiftly dimming world, a set of long, spiky limbs
sidle into view. With up to six pairs of legs,
these giant sea spiders aren’t arachnids, but rather a related class of marine
arthropod unique to the seafloor. In addition to housing some
of the animal’s organs, its legs are covered in tiny holes, which grow more numerous
as the spider ages. These holes will likely help absorb
the dissolved oxygen that saturates these freezing
southern waters. Since oxygen fuels growth, many local species have evolved
to take advantage of this abundance, and it may be one of the reasons that
gigantism is so common in this region. Individual sea spiders, for instance,
can grow to the size of dinner plates. But soon, these underwater giants
will be moving slower than ever. As winter settles in,
the sea floor becomes even colder. Waters fall to negative
1.8 degrees Celsius. On the surface, the thin icy crust
thickens into a layer called nilas, and young sea ice starts forming
ridges that block out the sun. The ocean begins to mirror
the still landscape above it. Antarctic sea cucumbers and urchins
go into dormancy for months, and their metabolic rates fall
to the slowest on Earth. Antarctic limpets continue feeding, but at such a gradual pace that they're
largely still surviving on energy reserves from the summer. Tiny crustaceans survive off the traces
of algae growing on their home’s icy ceiling, raising their young in these expansive
winter nurseries. But this seemingly endless winter
won't last forever. As spring comes, light slowly begins
to trickle back down through the ice. And week by week, bit by bit, this underwater world will begin waking up to begin its delicate,
slow-motion dance once again.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are invertebrates?
Options: A. Animals without a backbone, B. Animals with a backbone, C. Animals with scales, D. Animals with feathers
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate area covered by Antarctica's ice surface? Options: A. 1 million square kilometers, B. 3 million square kilometers, C. 5 million square kilometers, D. 7 million square kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 2: How long can giant Antarctic isopods survive without eating? Options: A. 10 days, B. 20 days, C. 30 days, D. 50 days Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the primary factor that supports the food chain in the Antarctic ecosystem during the summer season? Options: A. The formation of frazil ice, B. The abundance of oxygen in the waters, C. The phytoplankton blooms, D. The melting of sea ice Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why have species in Antarctica evolved to conserve energy? Options: A. Due to the abundance of food in the ecosystem, B. Due to the limited availability of food in the ecosystem, C. Due to the extreme temperatures in the ecosystem, D. Due to the need to adapt to changing seasons Correct Option: C

Question 7: What is the primary cause of the phytoplankton blooms that support the food chain in the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. The formation of frazil ice, B. The abundance of oxygen in the waters, C. The availability of sunlight, D. The upwelling of nutrients from the seafloor Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the effect of the changing seasons on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species? Options: A. It has no impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, B. It has a minimal impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, C. It has a significant impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, D. It has a variable impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 11: What is a key benefit of studying the Antarctic ecosystem and its unique species? Options: A. To exploit the ecosystem for resources such as fish and krill, B. To develop new products and technologies, C. To understand the impact of climate change on the ecosystem, D. To expand our knowledge of biodiversity and ecosystems Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is a crucial consideration when evaluating the effectiveness of conservation strategies for the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. The economic benefits of the strategies, B. The environmental impact of the strategies, C. The social implications of the strategies, D. The long-term sustainability of the ecosystem Correct Option: D
Question 13: How do giant Antarctic isopods adapt to the limited availability of food in the ecosystem? Options: A. By increasing their metabolism to find more food, B. By slowing their metabolism to conserve energy, C. By migrating to areas with more abundant food, D. By changing their diet to include more abundant food sources Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the role of sea cucumbers in the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. They are primary predators of phytoplankton, B. They are primary consumers of phytoplankton, C. They are decomposers that break down organic matter, D. They help to recycle nutrients through their waste Correct Option: D
Question 15: How do the changing seasons affect the behavior of Antarctic limpets? Options: A. They become more active and feed more frequently during the winter, B. They become less active and feed less frequently during the winter, C. They migrate to areas with more abundant food during the winter, D. They change their diet to include more abundant food sources during the winter Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast, white ice surface of Antarctica stretches for over 3 million
square kilometers: empty, desolate,
and almost completely silent. But appearances can be deceiving. On the coast of this expanse, just a few meters beneath the ice
lies a multicolored constellation of life. This remarkably diverse realm is home
to over 8,000 species of sea denizens who rely on an arsenal
of otherworldly traits to survive. So how do these species not only live,
but thrive, in conditions most animals
would be unable to bear? Antarctic waters are some of the most
consistently frigid in the world, hovering below 0 degrees Celsius
for a large portion of the year. This means burning energy
too quickly can be deadly, so survival in this ecosystem
looks slow and steady. Freezing temperatures persist
even in the summer, but this season brings
a rare gift: sunlight. For a brief period, it’s abundant, shining through the ice
for 24 hours a day. This infusion of energy drives intense
coastal phytoplankton blooms, transforming the waters
into a thick green soup. Marine life both large and small
takes advantage of this bounty, including the giant Antarctic isopod. Cousins of the humble pill bug, these crustaceans can reach
up to 11 centimeters long, and they never miss the opportunity
for a meal. The scavengers eat a wide variety of prey,
including other giant isopods. And by slowing their metabolisms,
they can make this food last, with one study showing specimens surviving
for 50 days without eating. Since this adaptation involves careful
conservation of energy, giant isopods spend most of their time
stationary or inching across the seafloor. Meanwhile, their tiny amphipod relatives
celebrate the summer by releasing offspring
alongside the algal explosion, ensuring their young have
an abundance of food. And sea cucumbers carpeting the seafloor
hoover up the dense plankton with outstretched
tentacles, producing nutrient-rich feces
that nourish nearby life. But this big summer blowout
doesn’t last long. The first signs of autumn arrive
in fine needles of frazil ice. These slowly coagulating crystals
form a skin across the surface, then mix with falling snow
before freezing into a thin crust of ice. The waters get darker and colder. And in this swiftly dimming world, a set of long, spiky limbs
sidle into view. With up to six pairs of legs,
these giant sea spiders aren’t arachnids, but rather a related class of marine
arthropod unique to the seafloor. In addition to housing some
of the animal’s organs, its legs are covered in tiny holes, which grow more numerous
as the spider ages. These holes will likely help absorb
the dissolved oxygen that saturates these freezing
southern waters. Since oxygen fuels growth, many local species have evolved
to take advantage of this abundance, and it may be one of the reasons that
gigantism is so common in this region. Individual sea spiders, for instance,
can grow to the size of dinner plates. But soon, these underwater giants
will be moving slower than ever. As winter settles in,
the sea floor becomes even colder. Waters fall to negative
1.8 degrees Celsius. On the surface, the thin icy crust
thickens into a layer called nilas, and young sea ice starts forming
ridges that block out the sun. The ocean begins to mirror
the still landscape above it. Antarctic sea cucumbers and urchins
go into dormancy for months, and their metabolic rates fall
to the slowest on Earth. Antarctic limpets continue feeding, but at such a gradual pace that they're
largely still surviving on energy reserves from the summer. Tiny crustaceans survive off the traces
of algae growing on their home’s icy ceiling, raising their young in these expansive
winter nurseries. But this seemingly endless winter
won't last forever. As spring comes, light slowly begins
to trickle back down through the ice. And week by week, bit by bit, this underwater world will begin waking up to begin its delicate,
slow-motion dance once again.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which season are there 24 hours of daylight?
Options: A. Winter, B. Summer, C. Autumn, D. Spring
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate area covered by Antarctica's ice surface? Options: A. 1 million square kilometers, B. 3 million square kilometers, C. 5 million square kilometers, D. 7 million square kilometers Correct Option: B
Question 2: How long can giant Antarctic isopods survive without eating? Options: A. 10 days, B. 20 days, C. 30 days, D. 50 days Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the primary factor that supports the food chain in the Antarctic ecosystem during the summer season? Options: A. The formation of frazil ice, B. The abundance of oxygen in the waters, C. The phytoplankton blooms, D. The melting of sea ice Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why have species in Antarctica evolved to conserve energy? Options: A. Due to the abundance of food in the ecosystem, B. Due to the limited availability of food in the ecosystem, C. Due to the extreme temperatures in the ecosystem, D. Due to the need to adapt to changing seasons Correct Option: C
Question 5: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 6: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the primary cause of the phytoplankton blooms that support the food chain in the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. The formation of frazil ice, B. The abundance of oxygen in the waters, C. The availability of sunlight, D. The upwelling of nutrients from the seafloor Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the effect of the changing seasons on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species? Options: A. It has no impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, B. It has a minimal impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, C. It has a significant impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species, D. It has a variable impact on the behavior and physiology of Antarctic species Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: (Removed question, no refinement needed) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 11: What is a key benefit of studying the Antarctic ecosystem and its unique species? Options: A. To exploit the ecosystem for resources such as fish and krill, B. To develop new products and technologies, C. To understand the impact of climate change on the ecosystem, D. To expand our knowledge of biodiversity and ecosystems Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is a crucial consideration when evaluating the effectiveness of conservation strategies for the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. The economic benefits of the strategies, B. The environmental impact of the strategies, C. The social implications of the strategies, D. The long-term sustainability of the ecosystem Correct Option: D
Question 13: How do giant Antarctic isopods adapt to the limited availability of food in the ecosystem? Options: A. By increasing their metabolism to find more food, B. By slowing their metabolism to conserve energy, C. By migrating to areas with more abundant food, D. By changing their diet to include more abundant food sources Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the role of sea cucumbers in the Antarctic ecosystem? Options: A. They are primary predators of phytoplankton, B. They are primary consumers of phytoplankton, C. They are decomposers that break down organic matter, D. They help to recycle nutrients through their waste Correct Option: D
Question 15: How do the changing seasons affect the behavior of Antarctic limpets? Options: A. They become more active and feed more frequently during the winter, B. They become less active and feed less frequently during the winter, C. They migrate to areas with more abundant food during the winter, D. They change their diet to include more abundant food sources during the winter Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast, white ice surface of Antarctica stretches for over 3 million
square kilometers: empty, desolate,
and almost completely silent. But appearances can be deceiving. On the coast of this expanse, just a few meters beneath the ice
lies a multicolored constellation of life. This remarkably diverse realm is home
to over 8,000 species of sea denizens who rely on an arsenal
of otherworldly traits to survive. So how do these species not only live,
but thrive, in conditions most animals
would be unable to bear? Antarctic waters are some of the most
consistently frigid in the world, hovering below 0 degrees Celsius
for a large portion of the year. This means burning energy
too quickly can be deadly, so survival in this ecosystem
looks slow and steady. Freezing temperatures persist
even in the summer, but this season brings
a rare gift: sunlight. For a brief period, it’s abundant, shining through the ice
for 24 hours a day. This infusion of energy drives intense
coastal phytoplankton blooms, transforming the waters
into a thick green soup. Marine life both large and small
takes advantage of this bounty, including the giant Antarctic isopod. Cousins of the humble pill bug, these crustaceans can reach
up to 11 centimeters long, and they never miss the opportunity
for a meal. The scavengers eat a wide variety of prey,
including other giant isopods. And by slowing their metabolisms,
they can make this food last, with one study showing specimens surviving
for 50 days without eating. Since this adaptation involves careful
conservation of energy, giant isopods spend most of their time
stationary or inching across the seafloor. Meanwhile, their tiny amphipod relatives
celebrate the summer by releasing offspring
alongside the algal explosion, ensuring their young have
an abundance of food. And sea cucumbers carpeting the seafloor
hoover up the dense plankton with outstretched
tentacles, producing nutrient-rich feces
that nourish nearby life. But this big summer blowout
doesn’t last long. The first signs of autumn arrive
in fine needles of frazil ice. These slowly coagulating crystals
form a skin across the surface, then mix with falling snow
before freezing into a thin crust of ice. The waters get darker and colder. And in this swiftly dimming world, a set of long, spiky limbs
sidle into view. With up to six pairs of legs,
these giant sea spiders aren’t arachnids, but rather a related class of marine
arthropod unique to the seafloor. In addition to housing some
of the animal’s organs, its legs are covered in tiny holes, which grow more numerous
as the spider ages. These holes will likely help absorb
the dissolved oxygen that saturates these freezing
southern waters. Since oxygen fuels growth, many local species have evolved
to take advantage of this abundance, and it may be one of the reasons that
gigantism is so common in this region. Individual sea spiders, for instance,
can grow to the size of dinner plates. But soon, these underwater giants
will be moving slower than ever. As winter settles in,
the sea floor becomes even colder. Waters fall to negative
1.8 degrees Celsius. On the surface, the thin icy crust
thickens into a layer called nilas, and young sea ice starts forming
ridges that block out the sun. The ocean begins to mirror
the still landscape above it. Antarctic sea cucumbers and urchins
go into dormancy for months, and their metabolic rates fall
to the slowest on Earth. Antarctic limpets continue feeding, but at such a gradual pace that they're
largely still surviving on energy reserves from the summer. Tiny crustaceans survive off the traces
of algae growing on their home’s icy ceiling, raising their young in these expansive
winter nurseries. But this seemingly endless winter
won't last forever. As spring comes, light slowly begins
to trickle back down through the ice. And week by week, bit by bit, this underwater world will begin waking up to begin its delicate,
slow-motion dance once again.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 15 days, B. 24 days, C. 50 days, D. 72 days
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
The vast, white ice surface of Antarctica stretches for over 3 million
square kilometers: empty, desolate,
and almost completely silent. But appearances can be deceiving. On the coast of this expanse, just a few meters beneath the ice
lies a multicolored constellation of life. This remarkably diverse realm is home
to over 8,000 species of sea denizens who rely on an arsenal
of otherworldly traits to survive. So how do these species not only live,
but thrive, in conditions most animals
would be unable to bear? Antarctic waters are some of the most
consistently frigid in the world, hovering below 0 degrees Celsius
for a large portion of the year. This means burning energy
too quickly can be deadly, so survival in this ecosystem
looks slow and steady. Freezing temperatures persist
even in the summer, but this season brings
a rare gift: sunlight. For a brief period, it’s abundant, shining through the ice
for 24 hours a day. This infusion of energy drives intense
coastal phytoplankton blooms, transforming the waters
into a thick green soup. Marine life both large and small
takes advantage of this bounty, including the giant Antarctic isopod. Cousins of the humble pill bug, these crustaceans can reach
up to 11 centimeters long, and they never miss the opportunity
for a meal. The scavengers eat a wide variety of prey,
including other giant isopods. And by slowing their metabolisms,
they can make this food last, with one study showing specimens surviving
for 50 days without eating. Since this adaptation involves careful
conservation of energy, giant isopods spend most of their time
stationary or inching across the seafloor. Meanwhile, their tiny amphipod relatives
celebrate the summer by releasing offspring
alongside the algal explosion, ensuring their young have
an abundance of food. And sea cucumbers carpeting the seafloor
hoover up the dense plankton with outstretched
tentacles, producing nutrient-rich feces
that nourish nearby life. But this big summer blowout
doesn’t last long. The first signs of autumn arrive
in fine needles of frazil ice. These slowly coagulating crystals
form a skin across the surface, then mix with falling snow
before freezing into a thin crust of ice. The waters get darker and colder. And in this swiftly dimming world, a set of long, spiky limbs
sidle into view. With up to six pairs of legs,
these giant sea spiders aren’t arachnids, but rather a related class of marine
arthropod unique to the seafloor. In addition to housing some
of the animal’s organs, its legs are covered in tiny holes, which grow more numerous
as the spider ages. These holes will likely help absorb
the dissolved oxygen that saturates these freezing
southern waters. Since oxygen fuels growth, many local species have evolved
to take advantage of this abundance, and it may be one of the reasons that
gigantism is so common in this region. Individual sea spiders, for instance,
can grow to the size of dinner plates. But soon, these underwater giants
will be moving slower than ever. As winter settles in,
the sea floor becomes even colder. Waters fall to negative
1.8 degrees Celsius. On the surface, the thin icy crust
thickens into a layer called nilas, and young sea ice starts forming
ridges that block out the sun. The ocean begins to mirror
the still landscape above it. Antarctic sea cucumbers and urchins
go into dormancy for months, and their metabolic rates fall
to the slowest on Earth. Antarctic limpets continue feeding, but at such a gradual pace that they're
largely still surviving on energy reserves from the summer. Tiny crustaceans survive off the traces
of algae growing on their home’s icy ceiling, raising their young in these expansive
winter nurseries. But this seemingly endless winter
won't last forever. As spring comes, light slowly begins
to trickle back down through the ice. And week by week, bit by bit, this underwater world will begin waking up to begin its delicate,
slow-motion dance once again.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the first stage of sea ice called?
Options: A. Frazil, B. Pancake, C. Pack ice, D. Nilas
Correct Option: A

Question: What reaction does increased daylight cause in coastal Antarctic waters?
Options: A. Lack of nutrients , B. Colder temperatures , C. Increased productivity in the form of phytoplankton blooms, D. Animals go into dormancy and retreat under rocks
Correct Option: C
